citation.article-title: Methylarcula marina gen. nov., sp. nov. and Methylarcula terricola sp. nov.: novel aerobic, moderately halophilic, facultatively methylotrophic bacteria from coastal saline environments.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methylarcula marina sp. nov.
Methylarcula marina (ma.ri'na. L. fem. n. mare sea; L. fem. adj. marina of the sea)
Has all the characteristics which define the genus.
Additionally, it has the following characteristics.
Colonies on methylamine agar medium (4-5 d) are white or pale pink, 1-2 mm in diameter.
Able to grow at 10-42 °C, pH 5.0-10.5 and 0.05-12% NaCl.
Optimal conditions for growth are 29-35 °C, pH 7.5-8.5 and 3-8% NaCl.
Utilizable carbon sources are methylamine, fructose, glucose, maltose, lactose, mannose, ribose, trehalose, galactose, xylose, sucrose, succinate, pyruvate and acetate.
Methylamine is oxidized to formaldehyde by the N-MG pathway enzymes: γ-GMA synthetase/lyase and NMG synthase/lyase.
The type strain Methylarcula marina h1T was isolated from the Azov Sea estuary water and is deposited in the Russian Collection of Microorganisms as VKM B-2159T.
